justification: The package contains only 1 class with 56 lines of code, which is not excessively large. The class FileSystemProviders has reasonable metrics with 6 methods and 7 weighted method count, indicating it has a focused responsibility and does not exhibit god component characteristics.

The package contains 32 classes with a total of 2709 lines of code. While the package has a considerable number of classes, they are cohesive and focused on file filtering functionality. The largest class, FileFilterUtils, has 469 lines of code and 43 methods, which is substantial but not excessive given its utility role. Classes are well-distributed in terms of responsibilities, and there is no single class that dominates the package in terms of complexity or lines of code disproportionately.

While the package contains a large number of classes (40) and significant lines of code (9478), the presence of multiple cohesive and logically grouped classes such as IOUtils, FileUtils, FilenameUtils, and others indicates a well-organized library structure rather than a single God Component. The responsibilities are distributed across specialized classes, each handling distinct aspects of I/O operations.

The package contains 17 classes with a total of 1633 lines of code, which is not excessively large for a package. The largest class, AbstractOrigin, has 614 lines of code and 19 methods, which is substantial but not excessively so given its role as an abstract base class with multiple inner classes. The classes appear to be well-organized around the builder pattern and file I/O abstractions, with reasonable separation of concerns. No single class dominates the package in terms of complexity or responsibility.

The package contains 34 classes with a total of 2198 lines of code. While the number of classes is relatively high, the lines of code are distributed across many small, focused classes (e.g., most classes have fewer than 100 LOC). Key classes like IOStream (394 LOC) and Uncheck (342 LOC) are large but still within reasonable limits for their functionality. The package appears to be a well-organized functional programming utility module rather than a single excessively large component.

The package contains only 7 classes with a total of 579 lines of code. The largest class, ValidatingObjectInputStream, has 278 lines of code and 17 methods, which is not excessively large in the context of this package. The other classes are significantly smaller, with most under 25 lines of code. There is no single component that dominates the package in terms of size or complexity.

The package contains only 1 class (FileTimes) with 225 lines of code. While the class has 24 methods and a WMC of 26, the size is not excessive for a single-purpose utility class in the context of file attribute operations. The package structure is simple and focused, without indication of taking on responsibilities beyond its designated scope.

The package contains 29 classes with a total of 3723 lines of code. While the package has a substantial size, the classes are functionally cohesive and focused on file and path operations. The largest class, PathUtils, has 1516 lines of code and 109 methods, which is significant but not excessively large in the context of its utility and responsibilities. Other classes are much smaller and well-scoped. The package does not exhibit the characteristics of a God Component as it maintains reasonable modularity and separation of concerns.

The package contains 52 classes with a total of 4700 lines of code. While the number of classes and LOC is relatively high, the classes are well-organized into cohesive units with clear responsibilities (e.g., OutputStream and Writer implementations). The average LOC per class is around 90, which is not excessively large. There is no single class or component that dominates the package in terms of complexity or functionality, indicating a reasonable distribution of responsibilities.

The package contains 7 classes with a total of 947 lines of code. The largest class, FileAlterationObserver, has 375 lines of code and 29 methods, which is substantial but not excessively large given its role as an observer in the file monitoring system. The distribution of responsibilities appears reasonable across the classes, with no single class dominating the functionality or LOC disproportionately. The package does not exhibit characteristics of a God Component as the size and complexity are contextually appropriate for its functionality.

The package contains only 3 classes with a total of 343 lines of code, which is not excessively large. The largest class, CircularByteBuffer, has 196 lines of code and 13 methods, which is also not excessive. The package and its classes exhibit reasonable size and complexity for their functionality.

The package contains only 4 classes with a total of 458 lines of code, which is not excessively large. The largest class, ByteArraySeekableByteChannel, has 202 lines of code and 18 methods, which is substantial but not unreasonable for a single class. The overall complexity and size of the package and its classes are within acceptable limits for typical software components.

The package contains 101 classes with a total of 10,353 lines of code. While this is a large package, the classes are well-organized into distinct functional units, each handling specific input stream or reader responsibilities. The largest classes (e.g., ObservableInputStream with 266 LOC, XmlStreamReader with 541 LOC) remain within reasonable complexity bounds. There is no single class or component that dominates the package in terms of size or responsibility, indicating good distribution of functionality.

The package contains 10 classes with a total of 490 lines of code, which is not excessively large. Each class has a well-defined responsibility related to file comparison, and the overall design follows a modular structure with low coupling and no signs of excessive centralization of functionality.

The package contains only 2 classes with a total of 48 lines of code, which is not excessively large. Each class has a low number of methods and lines of code (CharsetEncoders: 3 methods, 29 LOC; CharsetDecoders: 2 methods, 19 LOC). There are no signs of excessive complexity or centralization of functionality that would indicate a God Component.
